carouselRef: HTMLElement;\\\\n19: \\\\tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\\\\n20: \\\\n21: \\\\timport { onMount } from \\\\\\\"svelte\\\\\\\";\\\\n22: \\\\n23: \\\\tonMount(() => {\\\\n24: \\\\t\\\\t// Preload images\\\\n25: \\\\t\\\\ttestimonials.forEach((testimonial) => {\\\\n26: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (testimonial.image) {\\\\n27: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst img = new Image();\\\\n28: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\timg.loading = \\\\\\\"lazy\\\\\\\";\\\\n29: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\timg.src = testimonial.image;\\\\n30: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n31: \\\\t\\\\t});\\\\n32: \\\\n33: \\\\t\\\\t// Calculate the max scroll distance for translation\\\\n34: \\\\t\\\\tconst updateDimensions = () => {\\\\n35: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!carouselRef) return;\\\\n36: \\\\n37: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get all cards and container measurements\\\\n38: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\\\\\\\"article\\\\\\\"));\\\\n39: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!cards.length) return;\\\\n40: \\\\n41: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\\\\n42: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\\\\n43: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the viewport width\\\\n44: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\\\\n45: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the width of the last card\\\\n46: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\\\\n47: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\\\\n48: \\\\n49: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\\\\n50: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\\\\n51: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \\\\\\\"0px\\\\\\\";\\\\n52: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\\\\n53: \\\\n54: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\\\\n55: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\\\\n56: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\\\\n57: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\\\\n58: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\\\\n59: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\\\\n60: \\\\n61: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\\\\n62: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\\\\n63: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\\\\n64: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\\\\n65: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\\\\n66: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\\\\n67: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\\\\n68: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n69: \\\\n70: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\\\\n71: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconsole.info(\\\\\\\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\\\\\\\");\\\\n72: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n73: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n74: \\\\n75: \\\\t\\\\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\\\\n76: \\\\t\\\\tlet ticking = false;\\\\n77: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleScroll = () => {\\\\n78: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (ticking) return;\\\\n79: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = true;\\\\n80: \\\\n81: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\\\\n82: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\\\\n83: \\\\n84: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\\\\n85: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\\\\n86: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\\\\n87: \\\\n88: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\\\\n89: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tlet progress = 0;\\\\n90: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\\\\n91: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\\\\n92: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n93: \\\\n94: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tscrollProgress = progress;\\\\n95: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\\\\n96: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = false;\\\\n97: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t});\\\\n98: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n99: \\\\n100: \\\\t\\\\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\\\\n101: \\\\t\\\\tlet resizeTimer: number;\\\\n102: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleResize = () => {\\\\n103: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\\\\n104: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\\\\n105: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions();\\\\n106: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n107: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}, 100);\\\\n108: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n109: \\\\n110: \\\\t\\\\t// Initialize and set up listeners\\\\n111: \\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions();\\\\n112: \\\\t\\\\twindow.addEventListener(\\\\\\\"resize\\\\\\\", handleResize);\\\\n113: \\\\t\\\\twindow.addEventListener(\\\\\\\"scroll\\\\\\\", handleScroll);\\\\n114: \\\\t\\\\tsetTimeout(() => {\\\\n115: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\\\\n116: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n117: \\\\t\\\\t}, 100);\\\\n118: \\\\n119: \\\\t\\\\treturn () => {\\\\n120: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\twindow.removeEventListener(\\\\\\\"resize\\\\\\\", handleResize);\\\\n121: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\twindow.removeEventListener(\\\\\\\"scroll\\\\\\\", handleScroll);\\\\n122: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\\\\n123: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n124: \\\\t});\\\\n125: </script>\\\\n126: \\\\n127: <section\\\\n128: \\\\tbind:this={wrapperRef}\\\\n129: \\\\tclass=\\\\\\\"text-pretty [--gap:--spacing(4)]\\\\\\\"\\\\n130: \\\\tstyle=\\\\\\\"height: calc(100vh * {testimonials.length});\\\\\\\"\\\\n131: \\\\t{...rest}\\\\n132: >\\\\n133: \\\\t<div\\\\n134: \\\\t\\\\tclass=\\\\\\\"section-py section-px sticky top-0 flex min-h-screen w-full items-center <script lang=\"ts\">\n2: \t// Types\n3: \ttype Testimonial = {\n4: \t\tname: string;\n5: \t\tposition: string;\n6: \t\tcompany: string;\n7: \t\tquote: string;\n8: \t\timage: string; // a 9/16 portrait image of a person\n9: \t};\n10: \n11: \t// Props\n12: \tlet { testimonials, ...rest }: { testimonials: Testimonial[] } = $props();\n13: \n14: \t// State\n15: \tlet current = $state(0);\n16: \tlet scrollProgress = $state(0);\n17: \tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\n18: \tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\n19: \tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\n20: \n21: \timport { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n22: \n23: \tonMount(() => {\n24: \t\t// Preload images\n25: \t\ttestimonials.forEach((testimonial) => {\n26: \t\t\tif (testimonial.image) {\n27: \t\t\t\tconst img = new Image();\n28: \t\t\t\timg.loading = \"lazy\";\n29: \t\t\t\timg.src = testimonial.image;\n30: \t\t\t}\n31: \t\t});\n32: \n33: \t\t// Calculate the max scroll distance for translation\n34: \t\tconst updateDimensions = () => {\n35: \t\t\tif (!carouselRef) return;\n36: \n37: \t\t\t// Get all cards and container measurements\n38: \t\t\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\"article\"));\n39: \t\t\tif (!cards.length) return;\n40: \n41: \t\t\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\n42: \t\t\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\n43: \t\t\t// Get the viewport width\n44: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\n86: \t\t\t\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\n87: \n88: \t\t\t\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\n89: \t\t\t\tlet progress = 0;\n90: \t\t\t\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\n96: \t\t\t\tticking = false;\n97: \t\t\t});\n98: \t\t};\n99: \n100: \t\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\n101: \t\tlet resizeTimer: number;\n102: \t\tconst handleResize = () => {\n103: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n104: \t\t\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\n105: \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n113: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n114: \t\tsetTimeout(() => {\n115: \t\t\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\n116: \t\t\thandleScroll();\n117: \t\t}, 100);\n118: \n119: \t\treturn () => {\n120: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n121: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n122: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n123: \t\t};\n124: \t});\n125: </script>\n126: \n127: <section\n128: \tbind:this={wrapperRef}\n129: \tclass=\"text-pretty [--gap:--spacing(4)]\"\n130: \tstyle=\"height: calc(100vh * {testimonials.length});\"\n131: \t{...rest}\n132: >\n133: \t<div\n134: \t\tclass=\"section-py section-px sticky top-0 Flying is often associated with anxiety, uncertainty, hassle, and delays. By promising a stress-free experience, Flighty positions itself as a solution to these common travel woes. This speaks directly to the emotional needs of potential users.\\nCompleting the phrase \\\"stress-free flying\\\" creates a compelling vision of what air travel could be like with Flighty's help. It taps into the aspirational aspect of product marketing ‚Äî people aren't just buying an app ‚Äî they're buying into the idea of a more relaxed, enjoyable travel experience.\\nFinally, the use of \\\"Your\\\" personalizes the message. This makes it feel like Flighty is offering each individual user their own key to a better travel experience. This personal touch can make the app feel more accessible and relevant to potential users.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Like the sales assistant your team never had</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nFolk's marketing headline \\\"Like the sales assistant your team never had\\\" is a relatable situation and pitch.\\nBeginning the H1 with \\\"Like\\\" creates an immediate analogy that helps users understand Folk's core function. It frames the tool in human terms rather than technical features, making its value more relatable.\\nBy referencing \\\"sales assistant,\\\" the headline clearly positions Folk as a tool for sales teams while implying it handles administrative or support tasks. This suggests it frees up salespeople to focus on more important work.\\nAKA‚Ä¶ spending less time on busy work.\\nEnding the H1 with \\\"Your team never had\\\" implies Folk fills a gap or solves a problem that teams have been experiencing. It suggests the tool provides something missing, addressing an unmet need rather than just improving an existing process.\\nFinally, the headline avoids technical jargon about CRM features or data management. Instead, it focuses on the human role Folk plays in supporting sales teams, making it easier to connect with immediately.\\nOverall, this headline is effective because it positions Folk as a human-like assistant rather than just another sales tool.\\nCome for the CRM, stay for the sales assistant.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCentral's headline \\\"Payroll, benefits and government bullsh*t for startups\\\" is a bold and refreshingly honest marketing headline.\\nThe use of \\\"bullsh*t\\\" is deliberately provocative and authentic. It stands out and stops the scroll immediately. It acknowledges what many startup founders and operators truly feel about administrative tasks. They're bullsh*t. This honesty can create an immediate connection with the target audience.\\nBy listing \\\"Payroll, benefits and government\\\" before the expletive, the headline establishes credibility first before adding personality. This structure shows they understand the serious nature of these services while empathizing with their customers' frustrations.\\nTargeting \\\"for startups\\\" immediately identifies their core audience. There's no confusion here.\\nThis headline is effective because it strikes a delicate balance between professionalism and personality. It clearly communicates what Central does while using language that resonates with their target audience. The bold word choice makes the headline memorable and helps position Central as a company that understands startup culture and pain points.\\nHowever, like any headline using strong or edgy language, it does risk alienating some potential customers who might prefer more traditional corporate communication.\\nPros and cons‚Ä¶ but in this case the pros likely outweigh the cons.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>A discovery engine for creatives</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nCosmos's headline \\\"A discovery engine for creatives\\\" is a thought provoking headline that subtly addresses a common challenge for creatives ‚Äì finding new ideas or inspirations. This works for a few reasons.\\nThe term \\\"discovery engine\\\" is novel and intriguing. It suggests that Cosmos is more than just a search tool ‚Äì it's a system designed to uncover new and unexpected things. This phrasing elevates the product beyond a simple database or search engine.\\nBy specifically targeting creatives (one of their target markets cycled through) the headline immediately identifies and appeals to its core audience. This focus helps creatives quickly recognize that Cosmos is a tool designed with their needs in mind.\\nThe headline taps into the constant need for fresh inspiration and new ideas in creative fields. By positioning itself as a discovery tool, Cosmos aligns with the creative process of finding unexpected connections and inspiration.\\nThere's an implied promise of serendipity and surprise in this headline. For creatives who often seek out new inspirations and unconventional ideas, this suggestion of discovery is particularly appealing.\\nOverall, this is a thought provoking headline that leaves a potential user wanting more.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t</headline-examples>\\n   </headline-examples>\\n\\n   Do not use words from the banlist.\\n   <banlist>\\n   Bustling,\\nHarnessing,\\nUnveiling the power,\\nRealm,\\nDepicted,\\nDemistify,\\nInsurmountable,\\nNew Era,\\nPoised,\\nUnravel,\\nEntanglement,\\nUnprecedented,\\nEerie connection,\\nunliving,\\nBeacon,\\nUnleash,\\nDelve,\\nEnrich,\\nMultifaced,\\nElevate,\\nDiscover,\\nSupercharge,\\nUnlock,\\nUnleash,\\nTailored,\\nElegant,\\nDelve,\\nDive,\\nEver-evolving,\\npride,\\nRealm,\\nMeticulously,\\nGrappling,\\nWeighing,\\nPicture,\\nArchitect,\\nAdventure,\\nJourney,\\nEmbark,\\nNavigate,\\nNavigation,\\ndazzle,\\ntapestry,\\nRevolutionize,\\naugmented reality,\\nAR\\n   </banlist>\\n\\n  </writing_guide>\\n\\n## Mockup Tool\\n\\nYou are provided with a mockup tool which can be used to generate mockups to be used in images for the website.\\n\\nYou should always try to mix and match regular customer images with mockups so the site is always interesting and you break the pattern.\\n\\nThe mockup tool can currently generate the following mockups:\\n- airport-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a customer image inside an airport billboard.\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page.\\n\\n- dark-screen\\nThis mockup is a mockup of the company name and logo with a dark accent color background on a dark conference room screen\\nThis is best used in a hero section of an about page or careers page but of a dark mode website since this mockup is super dark, and will be too distracting on a light mode website.\\n\\n\\nMake sure to not use the same mockup in different places.\\n\\nRemember - you dont HAVE to always use the mockup tool, but you have the option to use it if you think it will help you create a better website and tel the story better.\\n\\n\\nYou will also be given a hero style for the hero section of the home page.\\nIf you're given a hero style which has left aligned or center aligned text, you need to use the correct hero and pass the prop (centered) correctly.\\n\\n- Make sure to use the correct hero style and import it and not hallucinate it.\\n- If in doubt, just use the default hero, or else use the ask_questions_to_codebase tool to ask the user for help.\\n- Always read the hero file to understand the props and how to use it correctly (centered, title, subtitle, image, testimonials, etc)\\n\\n## Company context\\nYou are building websites specifically for:\\n<company_context>\\nCompany name:\\nArchil\\n\\nWhat does the company do, in one sentence? (For example, X makes heavy machinery autonomous. X is building a mobile app for ... to help them with ...)\\nArchil provides infinitely-scaleable, shareable cloud volume storage that offers instant access to data sets in S3, designed for modern cloud applications with large, active data sets.\\n\\nWhich audiences does this company serve:\\nDevelopers, platform teams, data scientists, and teams building modern cloud applications, particularly those working with AI and analytics applications, observability platforms, and serverless data experiences like Jupyter Notebooks.\\n\\nWho founded the company:\\nHunter Leath\\n\\nOther important facts about the company, if mentioned (such as headquarters location, year founded, funding status, notable milestones, or any distinguishing features):\\nArchil was formerly known as Regatta Storage.\\nArchil is backed by Y Combinator and Felicis.\\nArchil is based in San Francisco.\\nArchil volumes provide up to 30x accelerated access speeds compared to S3 and up to 100x faster write workloads than shared file systems like Amazon EFS.\\nArchil offers cost savings of up to 90% over using EBS directly by only charging for actively used data.\\nArchil volumes are fully POSIX compliant.\\nArchil volumes support simultaneous access from multiple instances.\\nArchil volumes provide near-infinite capacity, designed to support petabytes of data.\\nArchil is SOC Type II, HIPAA, and GDPR compliant.\\nData stored in Archil volumes is automatically synchronized with a user-selected S3 bucket in its native format, preventing vendor lock-in.\\n\\nDetailed descriptions of the company's business model, products, services, and market positioning:\\nArchil provides cloud volume storage as a service. Their core product is Archil volumes, which are designed to address the challenges of managing large, active datasets in the cloud, particularly for modern applications like AI and analytics. The business model is based on usage, specifically charging only for the data that is actively being used within the Archil volumes. This contrasts with traditional block storage like EBS, where users provision and pay for a fixed amount of storage upfront, regardless of actual usage. Archil positions itself as the \\\"next step for active data in the cloud,\\\" offering a solution that simplifies data management, improves performance, and reduces costs compared to existing cloud storage options like EBS, S3, and shared file systems like EFS or FSx. Their key differentiators are infinite scalability, shareability across multiple instances, instant access to data in S3, high performance (lower latency than S3, faster writes than EFS), POSIX compliance for easy integration with existing applications, and a cost model based on active data usage.\\n\\nClearly identified founders, team members, and their professional backgrounds or previous ventures if mentioned:\\nHunter Leath is the Founder and CEO of Archil. His background includes spending 10 years in the cloud storage industry, leading teams at Amazon's Elastic File System and at Netflix. He has worked with hundreds of different data teams.\\n\\nAny explicitly stated partnerships, collaborations, or notable relationships:\\nArchil is backed by Y Combinator and Felicis.\\nArchil volumes offer out-of-the-box compatibility with Kubernetes, TensorFlow, Spark, Ray, PyTorch, Google Cloud, Azure, and Amazon Web Services (AWS).\\n\\nClearly defined potential customers, including a detailed explanation of the Ideal Customer Profile (ICP):\\nPotential customers include developers, platform teams, and data scientists.\\nThe Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) for Archil is likely organizations or teams that are building or running modern cloud applications that involve large, active datasets. This includes applications in areas such as AI and analytics, where large training datasets are common, and observability platforms that ingest and process petabytes of data. These customers are likely experiencing challenges with existing cloud storage solutions like EBS and S3, such as the complexity of managing capacity, the inability to easily share data across multiple instances, slow data access times for active datasets stored in S3, and high costs associated with over-provisioning storage. They are looking for a storage solution that offers infinite scalability, high performance for active data, seamless integration with S3, the ability to share data across instances, and a cost-effective model based on actual usage. Platform teams who want to build serverless data experiences for data scientists using S3 datasets are also a specific use case mentioned.\\n</company_context>\\n\\n\\nBe sure to remove ANY 'generating' props once you are done updating a component.\\n- ABSOLUTELY NEVER FORGET TO REMOVE THE GENERATING PROPS.\\n\"},{\"role\":\"user\",\"content\":\"<instructions>Write three testimonials, each digging into a bit time/risk/money save by the customer. \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\\\\n42: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\\\\n43: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the viewport width\\\\n44: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\\\\n45: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the width of the last card\\\\n46: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\\\\n47: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\\\\n48: \\\\n49: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\\\\n50: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst style = \\\\n54: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\\\\n55: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\\\\n56: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\\\\n57: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\\\\n58: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\\\\n59: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\\\\n60: \\\\n61: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\\\\n62: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\\\\n63: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\\\\n64: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\\\\n65: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\\\\n66: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\\\\n67: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\\\\n68: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n69: \\\\n70: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\\\\n71: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconsole.info(\\\\\\\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\\\\\\\");\\\\n72: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n73: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n74: \\\\n75: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\\\\n92: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n93: \\\\n94: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tscrollProgress = progress;\\\\n95: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\\\\n96: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = false;\\\\n97: handleScroll);\\\\n114: \\\\t\\\\tsetTimeout(() => {\\\\n115: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\\\\n116: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n117: \\\\t\\\\t}, <script lang=\"ts\">\n2: \t// Types\n3: \ttype Testimonial = {\n4: \t\tname: string;\n5: \t\tposition: string;\n6: \t\tcompany: string;\n7: \t\tquote: string;\n8: \t\timage: string; // a 9/16 portrait image of a person\n9: \t};\n10: \n11: \t// Props\n12: \tlet { testimonials, ...rest }: { testimonials: Testimonial[] } = $props();\n13: \n14: \t// State\n15: \tlet current = $state(0);\n16: \tlet scrollProgress = $state(0);\n17: \tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\n18: \tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\n19: \tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\n20: \n21: \timport { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n22: \n23: \tonMount(() => {\n24: \t\t// Preload images\n25: \t\ttestimonials.forEach((testimonial) => {\n26: \t\t\tif (testimonial.image) {\n27: \t\t\t\tconst img = new Image();\n28: \t\t\t\timg.loading = \"lazy\";\n29: \t\t\t\timg.src = testimonial.image;\n30: \t\t\t}\n31: \t\t});\n32: \n33: \t\t// Calculate the max scroll distance for translation\n34: \t\tconst updateDimensions = () => {\n35: \t\t\tif (!carouselRef) return;\n36: \n37: \t\t\t// Get all cards and container measurements\n38: \t\t\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\"article\"));\n39: \t\t\tif (!cards.length) return;\n40: \n41: \t\t\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\n42: \t\t\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\n43: \t\t\t// Get the viewport width\n44: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\n86: \t\t\t\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\n87: \n88: \t\t\t\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\n89: \t\t\t\tlet progress = 0;\n90: \t\t\t\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\n96: \t\t\t\tticking = false;\n97: \t\t\t});\n98: \t\t};\n99: \n100: \t\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\n101: \t\tlet resizeTimer: number;\n102: \t\tconst handleResize = () => {\n103: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n104: \t\t\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\n105: \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n113: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n114: \t\tsetTimeout(() => {\n115: \t\t\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\n116: \t\t\thandleScroll();\n117: \t\t}, 100);\n118: \n119: \t\treturn () => {\n120: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n121: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n122: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n123: \t\t};\n124: \t});\n125: </script>\n126: \n127: <section\n128: \tbind:this={wrapperRef}\n129: \tclass=\"text-pretty [--gap:--spacing(4)]\"\n130: \tstyle=\"height: calc(100vh * {testimonials.length});\"\n131: \t{...rest}\n132: >\n133: \t<div\n134: \t\tclass=\"section-py section-px sticky top-0 flex min-h-screen w-full items-center overflow-hidden\"\n135: \t>\n136: \t\t<div\n137: \t\t\tbind:this={carouselRef}\n138: \t\t\tclass={[\n139: \t\t\t\t\"flex w-full gap-(--card-gap) pr-8 [--card-gap:--spacing(6)]\",\n140: \t\t\t\t\"[--inner-radius:calc(var(--outer-radius)-var(--gap))] [--outer-radius:var(--radius)] lg:[--outer-radius:var(--radius-xl)]\"\n141: \t\t\t]}\n142: \t\t>\n143: \t\t\t{#each testimonials as testimonial}\n144: \t\t\t\t<article\n145: \t\t\t\t\tclass={[\n146: \t\t\t\t\t\t\"lg:container-xs  lg:min-w-[50%] lg:grid-cols-[2fr_3fr]\",\n147: This approach can make the product feel more accessible and appealing.\\nTake a note from Attio's playbook and make your headline magical.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Your shortcut to everything.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nRaycast's H1 \\\"Your shortcut to everything\\\" is a powerful and effective marketing headline that immediately made us stop and read on.\\nThe headline leverages the universally appealing concept of efficiency. In our fast-paced digital world, the promise of quicker and easier ways to accomplish tasks is highly attractive to many consumers.\\n\\\"Everything\\\" is a bold and ambitious term that piques curiosity. It implies that Raycast can be customized to fit the user's specific needs, rather than being a one-size-fits-all solution.\\n10/10 headline.\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t</description>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t</headline>\\n\\t\\t\\n\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t<headline>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<h1>Refreshingly simple project management.</h1>\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t<description>\\nEveryone is familiar with Basecamp. (For example, X makes heavy machinery autonomous. X is building a mobile app for ... to help them with ...)\\nArchil provides infinitely-scaleable, shareable cloud volume storage that offers instant access to data sets in S3, designed for modern cloud applications with large, active data sets.\\n\\nWhich audiences does this company serve:\\nDevelopers, platform teams, data scientists, and teams building modern cloud applications, particularly those working with AI and analytics applications, observability platforms, and serverless data experiences like Jupyter Notebooks.\\n\\nWho founded the company:\\nHunter Leath\\n\\nOther important facts about the company, if mentioned (such as headquarters location, year founded, funding status, notable milestones, or any distinguishing features):\\nArchil was formerly known as Regatta Storage.\\nArchil is backed by Y Combinator and Felicis.\\nArchil is based in San Francisco.\\nArchil volumes provide up to 30x accelerated access speeds compared to S3 and up to 100x faster write workloads than shared file systems like Amazon EFS.\\nArchil offers cost savings of up to 90% over using EBS directly by only charging for actively used data.\\nArchil volumes are fully POSIX compliant.\\nArchil volumes support simultaneous access from multiple instances.\\nArchil volumes provide near-infinite capacity, designed to support petabytes of data.\\nArchil is SOC Type II, HIPAA, and GDPR compliant.\\nData stored in Archil volumes is automatically synchronized with a user-selected S3 bucket in its native format, preventing vendor lock-in.\\n\\nDetailed descriptions of the company's business model, products, services, and market positioning:\\nArchil provides cloud volume storage as a service. Their core product is Archil volumes, which are designed to address the challenges of managing large, active datasets in the cloud, particularly for modern applications like AI and analytics. The business model is based on usage, specifically charging only for the data that is actively being used within the Archil volumes. This contrasts with traditional block storage like EBS, where users provision and pay for a fixed amount of storage upfront, regardless of actual usage. Archil positions itself as the \\\"next step for active data in the cloud,\\\" offering a solution that simplifies data management, improves performance, and reduces costs compared to existing cloud storage options like EBS, S3, and shared file systems like EFS or FSx. Their key differentiators are infinite scalability, shareability across multiple instances, instant access to data in S3, high performance (lower latency than S3, faster writes than EFS), POSIX compliance for easy integration with existing applications, and a cost model based on active data usage.\\n\\nClearly identified founders, team members, and their professional backgrounds or previous ventures if mentioned:\\nHunter Leath is the Founder and CEO of Archil. His background includes spending 10 years in the cloud storage industry, leading teams at Amazon's Elastic File System and at Netflix. This includes applications in areas such as AI and analytics, where large training datasets are common, and observability platforms that ingest and process petabytes of data. These customers are likely experiencing challenges with existing cloud storage solutions like EBS and S3, such as the complexity of managing capacity, the inability to easily share data across multiple instances, slow data access times for active datasets stored in S3, and high costs associated with over-provisioning storage. They are looking for a storage solution that offers infinite scalability, high performance for active data, seamless integration with S3, the ability to share data across instances, and a cost-effective model based on actual usage. <script lang=\\\\\\\"ts\\\\\\\">\\\\n2: \\\\t// Types\\\\n3: \\\\ttype Testimonial = {\\\\n4: \\\\t\\\\tname: string;\\\\n5: \\\\t\\\\tposition: string;\\\\n6: \\\\t\\\\tcompany: string;\\\\n7: \\\\t\\\\tquote: string;\\\\n8: \\\\t\\\\timage: string; // a 9/16 portrait image of a person\\\\n9: \\\\t};\\\\n10: \\\\n11: \\\\t// Props\\\\n12: \\\\tlet { testimonials, ...rest }: { testimonials: Testimonial[] } = $props();\\\\n13: \\\\n14: \\\\t// State\\\\n15: \\\\tlet current = $state(0);\\\\n16: \\\\tlet scrollProgress = $state(0);\\\\n17: \\\\tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\\\\n18: \\\\tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\\\\n19: \\\\tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\\\\n20: \\\\n21: \\\\timport { onMount } from \\\\\\\"svelte\\\\\\\";\\\\n22: \\\\n23: \\\\tonMount(() => {\\\\n24: \\\\t\\\\t// Preload images\\\\n25: \\\\t\\\\ttestimonials.forEach((testimonial) => {\\\\n26: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (testimonial.image) {\\\\n27: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst img = new Image();\\\\n28: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\timg.loading = \\\\\\\"lazy\\\\\\\";\\\\n29: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\timg.src = testimonial.image;\\\\n30: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n31: \\\\t\\\\t});\\\\n32: \\\\n33: \\\\t\\\\t// Calculate the max scroll distance for translation\\\\n34: \\\\t\\\\tconst updateDimensions = () => {\\\\n35: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!carouselRef) return;\\\\n36: \\\\n37: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get all cards and container measurements\\\\n38: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\\\\\\\"article\\\\\\\"));\\\\n39: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!cards.length) return;\\\\n40: \\\\n41: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\\\\n42: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\\\\n43: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the viewport width\\\\n44: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\\\\n45: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get the width of the last card\\\\n46: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\\\\n47: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\\\\n48: \\\\n49: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\\\\n50: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\\\\n51: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \\\\\\\"0px\\\\\\\";\\\\n52: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\\\\n53: \\\\n54: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\\\\n55: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\\\\n56: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\\\\n57: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\\\\n58: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\\\\n59: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\\\\n60: \\\\n61: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\\\\n62: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\\\\n63: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\\\\n64: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\\\\n65: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\\\\n66: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\\\\n67: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\\\\n68: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n69: \\\\n70: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\\\\n71: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconsole.info(\\\\\\\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\\\\\\\");\\\\n72: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n73: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n74: \\\\n75: \\\\t\\\\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\\\\n76: \\\\t\\\\tlet ticking = false;\\\\n77: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleScroll = () => {\\\\n78: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (ticking) return;\\\\n79: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = true;\\\\n80: \\\\n81: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\\\\n82: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\\\\n83: \\\\n84: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\\\\n85: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\\\\n86: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\\\\n87: \\\\n88: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\\\\n89: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tlet progress = 0;\\\\n90: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\\\\n91: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\\\\n92: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}\\\\n93: \\\\n94: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tscrollProgress = progress;\\\\n95: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\\\\n96: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tticking = false;\\\\n97: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t});\\\\n98: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n99: \\\\n100: \\\\t\\\\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\\\\n101: \\\\t\\\\tlet resizeTimer: number;\\\\n102: \\\\t\\\\tconst handleResize = () => {\\\\n103: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\\\\n104: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\\\\n105: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\tupdateDimensions();\\\\n106: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\\\thandleScroll();\\\\n107: \\\\t\\\\t\\\\t}, 100);\\\\n108: \\\\t\\\\t};\\\\n109: \\\\n110: \\\\t\\\\t// Initialize and set up listeners\\\\n111: scrollProgress = $state(0);\n17: \tlet wrapperRef: HTMLElement;\n18: \tlet carouselRef: HTMLElement;\n19: \tlet maxScrollDistance = $state(0);\n20: \n21: \timport { onMount } from \"svelte\";\n22: \"lazy\";\n29: \t\t\t\timg.src = testimonial.image;\n30: \t\t\t}\n31: \t\t});\n32: \n33: \t\t// Calculate the max scroll distance for translation\n34: \t\tconst updateDimensions = () => {\n35: \t\t\tif (!carouselRef) return;\n36: \n37: \t\t\t// Get all cards and container measurements\n38: \t\t\tconst cards = Array.from(carouselRef.querySelectorAll(\"article\"));\n39: \t\t\tif (!cards.length) return;\n40: \n41: \t\t\t// Get the total width of all content including gaps\n42: \t\t\tconst carouselWidth = carouselRef.scrollWidth;\n43: \t\t\t// Get the viewport width\n44: \t\t\tconst viewportWidth = window.innerWidth;\n45: \t\t\t// Get the width of the last card\n46: \t\t\tconst lastCard = cards[cards.length - 1];\n47: \t\t\tconst lastCardWidth = lastCard.offsetWidth;\n48: \n49: \t\t\t// Get computed styles to account for gaps and padding\n50: \t\t\tconst style = getComputedStyle(carouselRef);\n51: \t\t\tconst gapStr = style.gap || style.columnGap || \"0px\";\n52: \t\t\tconst gapValue = parseInt(gapStr, 10) || 0;\n53: \n54: \t\t\t// To ensure the last card is fully visible at the end of the scroll,\n55: \t\t\t// we need to make sure the last card's right edge aligns with the viewport's right edge\n56: \t\t\t// This means the maximum distance we need to translate is:\n57: \t\t\t// (total carousel width - viewport width)\n58: \t\t\t// If this value is negative or zero, no scrolling is needed\n59: \t\t\tmaxScrollDistance = Math.max(0, carouselWidth - viewportWidth);\n60: \n61: \t\t\t// Ensure we can see the last card fully\n62: \t\t\t// This extra adjustment ensures the last card is properly positioned at the end of the scroll\n63: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance > 0) {\n64: \t\t\t\t// Add a larger buffer for more breathing room at the right edge\n65: \t\t\t\t// This accounts for any padding or margin that might affect positioning\n66: \t\t\t\tconst buffer = 0; // 4rem buffer instead of 1rem\n67: \t\t\t\tmaxScrollDistance += buffer;\n68: \t\t\t}\n69: \n70: \t\t\tif (maxScrollDistance <= 0) {\n71: \t\t\t\tconsole.info(\"Content fits in viewport, no scrolling needed\");\n72: \t\t\t}\n73: \t\t};\n74: \n75: \t\t// Track vertical scroll position and convert to horizontal scroll\n76: \t\tlet ticking = false;\n77: \t\tconst handleScroll = () => {\n78: \t\t\tif (ticking) return;\n79: \t\t\tticking = true;\n80: \n81: \t\t\trequestAnimationFrame(() => {\n82: \t\t\t\tif (!wrapperRef) return;\n83: \n84: \t\t\t\tconst rect = wrapperRef.getBoundingClientRect();\n85: \t\t\t\tconst sectionHeight = rect.height;\n86: \t\t\t\tconst viewportHeight = window.innerHeight;\n87: \n88: \t\t\t\t// Calculate progress (0-1)\n89: \t\t\t\tlet progress = 0;\n90: \t\t\t\tif (rect.top <= 0) {\n91: \t\t\t\t\tprogress = Math.min(Math.abs(rect.top) / (sectionHeight - viewportHeight), 1);\n92: \t\t\t\t}\n93: \n94: \t\t\t\tscrollProgress = progress;\n95: \t\t\t\tcurrent = Math.min(Math.floor(progress * testimonials.length), testimonials.length - 1);\n96: \t\t\t\tticking = false;\n97: \t\t\t});\n98: \t\t};\n99: \n100: \t\t// Debounce resize handler for better performance\n101: \t\tlet resizeTimer: number;\n102: \t\tconst handleResize = () => {\n103: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n104: \t\t\tresizeTimer = setTimeout(() => {\n105: \t\t\t\tupdateDimensions();\n106: \t\t\t\thandleScroll();\n107: \t\t\t}, 100);\n108: \t\t};\n109: \n110: \t\t// Initialize and set up listeners\n111: \t\tupdateDimensions();\n112: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n113: \t\twindow.addEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n114: \t\tsetTimeout(() => {\n115: \t\t\tupdateDimensions(); // Run once more after DOM is settled\n116: \t\t\thandleScroll();\n117: \t\t}, 100);\n118: \n119: \t\treturn () => {\n120: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"resize\", handleResize);\n121: \t\t\twindow.removeEventListener(\"scroll\", handleScroll);\n122: \t\t\tclearTimeout(resizeTimer);\n123: \t\t};\n124: \t});\n125: </script>\n126: \n127: <section\n128: \tbind:this={wrapperRef}\n129:
